Convert parameters to optimizable form

Source: R/p_to_optim.R
p_to_optim.Rd

p_to_optim converts a parameter list into a form suitable for optimization by transforming the parameters and computing their derivatives. This function handles the transformation of both fixed and random effect parameters.

Usage

p_to_optim(p)

Arguments

p

A list containing the parameter structure:

  • beta: Vector of population parameters

  • Omega: Covariance matrix for random effects

  • Sigma_prop: Proportional error variance (optional)

  • Sigma_add: Additive error variance (optional)

Value

A list containing:

  • values: Transformed parameter values

  • backtransformfunc: Function to back-transform parameters

  • d_psi_d_psitrans_long: Derivatives of the transformation

  • d_bi_d_omega: Derivatives of random effects with respect to Omega

  • d_omega_d_Omega: Derivatives of omega with respect to Omega

Details

The function performs several transformations:

  • Log-transforms positive parameters (beta and diagonal elements of Omega)

  • Transforms correlation parameters using the inverse hyperbolic tangent

  • Computes derivatives for the transformation

  • Handles fixed parameters (specified as strings)

The back-transformation function can be used to convert the optimized parameters back to their original scale. The derivatives are used in the optimization process to compute gradients and Hessians.

Examples

# Define parameters
p <- list(
  beta = c(cl = 5, v1 = 10, v2 = 30, q = 10, ka = 1),
  Omega = matrix(c(0.09, 0, 0, 0, 0,
                  0, 0.09, 0, 0, 0,
                  0, 0, 0.09, 0, 0,
                  0, 0, 0, 0.09, 0,
                  0, 0, 0, 0, 0.09), nrow = 5, ncol = 5),
  Sigma_prop = 0.04
)

# Convert to optimizable form
p_optim <- p_to_optim(p)

# Back-transform parameters
p_orig <- p_optim$backtransformfunc(p_optim$values)
